head.title: Wisdom for the Ages, by Book, Not Chip

hedline.hl1: Wisdom for the Ages, by Book, Not Chip

abstract.p: Richard A Fireman letter questions practice of separating bibliographies from the text of books and putting them on line (May 29 article)

block.p: A May 29 front-page article discusses the new practice of separating bibliographies from the text of books and putting them on the Internet. We might well worry.

Books are not just a passing convenience. They are the way we communicate across the centuries. Ours is the first generation whose wisdom is being electronically stored, where it cannot be read without the appropriate technology.
A May 29 front-page article discusses the new practice of separating bibliographies from the text of books and putting them on the Internet. We might well worry.

Books are not just a passing convenience. They are the way we communicate across the centuries. Ours is the first generation whose wisdom is being electronically stored, where it cannot be read without the appropriate technology.
What happens if the technology is lost -- through gradual change or catastrophic destruction? All of our knowledge could be lost.
We can still view the cave drawings and stone inscriptions of human civilizations long gone. But who will be able to read our writings?
